Topic.Title: Obama: How Much Socialism is "just right" in a society

Message.Msg: The European Union generates a GDP of $17.58 trillion and a public debt of 85% of GDP. The USA generates a GDP of $15.61 trillion with a public debt 101% of GDP. Sorry was it the USA or Europe you said had the problem managing its economy? Singapore is not a viable economic model for an economy the size of a continent. That's like saying Europe should adopt the economic model of the Principality of Monaco - offer low taxes but raise property prices so only high rollers can afford to live there.
47% is the best comment ever. Liberals now see that most of their party is made up of TAKERS and not followers of their liberal ideas.
The election will have little impact on the stock market. It is expected that Obama stays in office. The fiscal cliff may cause some problems for investors? But, that will be solved before long.

Message.Title: Three Weeks Tight
Message.Msg: If IBM closes this week within one percent of $206.81 it will have formed a three weeks tight pattern. The volume is really drying up in this stock and it indicates that after the big move from $193 to $206 that investors are holding on and not willing to sell their shares. Typically, this pattern precedes a leg up in a stock. Even though INTC, ADBE, TXN, CAT and other multi-national firms have lowered guidance, the software and services space is holding up well. ORCL and TIBX reported solid quarters last week, and I suspect IBM will beat and raise at the October EPS report. IBM is up about 12% this year (not including dividends) and should close the year around $220...

IBM will soon be trading on 2013 EPS numbers which should be north of $17! With that type of earnings power, and the % growth of earnings, I expect IBM to trade over $250 in 2013 which is another 12% gain (excluding dividends).

Message.Title: CNBC broke the market today
Message.Msg: The crash is coming and HFT are back

Topic.Title: Obama: How Much Socialism is "just right" in a society

Message.Msg: ... whereas Singapore has low taxes, high growth and low unemployment... symptomatic of a supply-side culture. Asia has 2, financial centers... Hong Kong in North asia, and Singapore in south asia. To say that Singapore is an insufficient example of a sovereign national economy is the craziest thing I've heard this year. Keynsianism is popular in anti-capitalist, hate-the-rich societies... Supply-side economics is popular in countries that prefer to unleash the immense power of capitalism to foster growth and prosperity without regard for how rich the people are who are hiring all it's citizens. The Brazillian founder of Facebook fled the U.S. economy in favor of Singapore and now THEY are enjoying the fruits of his $3 billion in investments. Today, I heard that Apple's Steve Wozniack was fleeing american class-envy in favor of the more capital-friendly location of Australia. I'm sure HIS fortune will contribute to a lot of business development and jobs in THAT country. S

Topic.Title: Obama: How Much Socialism is "just right" in a society

Message.Msg: My point was that the Singapore State has ownership in industries that compose 60% of the state's economy through Temasek sovereign wealth fund. This is somewhat similar to the French economic model, but this degree of nationalization of core industries would be unthinkable in the USA.

Topic.Title: Obama: How Much Socialism is "just right" in a society

Message.Msg: Sorry to pop your bubble here. The Singapore stock exchange has a market cap of roughly $500 billion, and doesn't make the list of 20 largest exchanges, However Japan is 3rd, Shanghai 6th, Hong Kong 7th, Shenzen 13th, Bombay 15th, Seoul 16th and, Nation SE of India 17th
